reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s use of “WAM-convergence” as a benchmark and its realism/anti-realism fork in §2.4, claiming this makes the WAM category incoherent or unstable and thus undermines the paper’s scenario-partition. That is moderately central: WAM is a major organizing concept in section 2, but the paper’s overall thrust is that WAM is unlikely and that partial AM + trade is the more promising path, so even if WAM were ill-posed the main conclusion could largely survive with reframing. The argument has some force in highlighting a tension: if ‘accuracy’ is cashed out in different ways across metaethics, treating WAM as a unified yardstick can be conceptually slippery. However, it overstates: anti-realism needn’t make ‘accuracy’ incoherent (it can be indexed to idealized/endorsed standards), and realism doesn’t imply the truth is motivationally ‘toxic’ or generally avoided; the paper itself already gestures at these nuances. So it weakens the framing more than it refutes the substance. The critique is clear, focused, and has little filler.
title: Meta-ethical ecumenism makes "accurate convergence" either incoherent or self-defeating
